trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Virtual Machines and then select the virtual machine you just created (testlinuxvm).
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Virtual Machines and then select the virtual machine you just created (testlinuxvm).

trans-unit.source: On the command bar click Attach and then click Attach Empty Disk.
trans-unit.target: On the command bar click Attach and then click Attach Empty Disk.

trans-unit.source: The Attach Empty Disk dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Attach Empty Disk dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: The Virtual Machine Name, Storage Location, and File Name are already defined for you.
trans-unit.target: The Virtual Machine Name, Storage Location, and File Name are already defined for you.

trans-unit.source: All you have to do is enter the size that you want for the disk.
trans-unit.target: All you have to do is enter the size that you want for the disk.

trans-unit.source: Type 5 in the Size field.
trans-unit.target: Type 5 in the Size field.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Attach Empty Disk</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Attach Empty Disk</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note: All disks are created from a .vhd file in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: Note: All disks are created from a .vhd file in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: You can provide a name for the .vhd file that is added to storage, but Azure generates the name of the disk automatically.
trans-unit.target: You can provide a name for the .vhd file that is added to storage, but Azure generates the name of the disk automatically.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark to attach the data disk to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark to attach the data disk to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Click the name of the virtual machine to display the dashboard so you can verify that the data disk was successfully attached to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Click the name of the virtual machine to display the dashboard so you can verify that the data disk was successfully attached to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The disk that you attached is listed in the Disks table.
trans-unit.target: The disk that you attached is listed in the Disks table.

trans-unit.source: When you attach a data disk, it's not ready for use until you log in to complete the setup.
trans-unit.target: When you attach a data disk, it's not ready for use until you log in to complete the setup.

trans-unit.source: Connect to the Virtual Machine Using SSH or PuTTY and Complete Setup
trans-unit.target: Connect to the Virtual Machine Using SSH or PuTTY and Complete Setup

trans-unit.source: Log on to the virtual machine to complete setup of the disk so you can use it to store data.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the virtual machine to complete setup of the disk so you can use it to store data.

trans-unit.source: After the virtual machine is provisioned, connect using SSH or PuTTY and login as newuser (as described in the steps above).
trans-unit.target: After the virtual machine is provisioned, connect using SSH or PuTTY and login as newuser (as described in the steps above).

trans-unit.source: In the SSH or PuTTY window type the following command and then enter the account password:
trans-unit.target: In the SSH or PuTTY window type the following command and then enter the account password:

trans-unit.source: $ sudo grep SCSI /var/log/messages
trans-unit.target: $ sudo grep SCSI /var/log/messages

trans-unit.source: You can find the identifier of the last data disk that was added in the messages that are displayed (sdc, in this example).
trans-unit.target: You can find the identifier of the last data disk that was added in the messages that are displayed (sdc, in this example).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>GREP</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>GREP</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the SSH or PuTTY window, enter the following command to partition the disk /dev/sdc:
trans-unit.target: In the SSH or PuTTY window, enter the following command to partition the disk /dev/sdc:

trans-unit.source: $ sudo fdisk /dev/sdc
trans-unit.target: $ sudo fdisk /dev/sdc

trans-unit.source: Enter n to create a new partition.
trans-unit.target: Enter n to create a new partition.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type p to make the partition the primary partition, type 1 to make it the first partition, and then type enter to accept the default value (1) for the cylinder.
trans-unit.target: Type p to make the partition the primary partition, type 1 to make it the first partition, and then type enter to accept the default value (1) for the cylinder.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type p to see the details about the disk that is being partitioned.
trans-unit.target: Type p to see the details about the disk that is being partitioned.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type w to write the settings for the disk.
trans-unit.target: Type w to write the settings for the disk.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>FDISK</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Format the new disk using the mkfs command:
trans-unit.target: Format the new disk using the mkfs command:

trans-unit.source: $ sudo mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sdc1
trans-unit.target: $ sudo mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sdc1

trans-unit.source: Next you must have a directory available to mount the new file system.
trans-unit.target: Next you must have a directory available to mount the new file system.

trans-unit.source: As an example, type the following command to make a new directory for mounting the drive, and then enter the account password:
trans-unit.target: As an example, type the following command to make a new directory for mounting the drive, and then enter the account password:

trans-unit.source: sudo mkdir /datadrive
trans-unit.target: sudo mkdir /datadrive

trans-unit.source: Type the following command to mount the drive:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command to mount the drive:

trans-unit.source: sudo mount /dev/sdc1 /datadrive
trans-unit.target: sudo mount /dev/sdc1 /datadrive

trans-unit.source: The data disk is now ready to use as /datadrive.
trans-unit.target: The data disk is now ready to use as /datadrive.

trans-unit.target: To ensure the drive is re-mounted automatically after a reboot it must be added to the /etc/fstab file.
